name: The Fairbanks Four / Hoodie - White
description:
This design represents the beauty, strength, and struggle of Native America. When the Whites so called “settled” the land, we were very much at bloody war with each other. Beaten with all the technology and diseases carried against the tribes of America, the Natives were pushed into villages and reservations in some of the toughest lands far from the birth of the American dreams. Today most Natives still set in these communities plagued with 3rd world living conditions, no industry, and a lack of understanding on how to deal with this new way of life. In these Native communities we still live with the strong culture of our ancestors, but we also still share the pain of their death and struggle from this defeat.

I believe that we can overcome this struggle by recognizing where we are at, accepting it, and moving on. I wanted to do this design to bring our struggle to light and also to show the beauty and strength that we also carry. If we can embrace our dancing, singing, language, and traditional foods, we will give much needed breath to the heart of our pride and way of life. 

All profits go to the Alaska Innocence Project in support of the wrongfully convicted Fairbanks Four

name: Always Ready / Shirt - Neon Green
description:
“ALWAYS READY”

“Always Ready” is a design that represents what is needed in life to take on the strongest challenges coming at you. I did this design in hopes of resurrecting that strong spirit of our past ancestors who ensured our survival by never giving up and facing challenges that today would seem impossible. There are stories of our forefathers running down caribou with snow shoes in freezing cold winters and killing them with bows. When a moose track was found in the snow, a hunter and his party would follow the animal sometimes for weeks to ensure his tribes survival. During these hunts, the Natives would have to hunt and eat small game such as spruce grouse, rabbits, lynx, etc.. until ﬁnally harvesting the big catch and bringing it back to their tribe.

Too many times today our people are depicted as a beaten and broken race. Like the dying Indian slumped over his horse, or the crying Indian walking down a road littered with debris. It is as if we are being played as a broken group of people that are defenseless to the hardships and challenges that is faced in today's society.

In the past there were many times of war, hunger, and nomadic hardships, but no matter the situation coming at them, never once did the men and women warriors ever have the word “quit” in their minds. 

Today has many challenges, while not the same as in the past, it certainly may end in death all the same. 

But like our ancestors we must push on and face any challenges coming and know with conﬁdence in our hearts that we are always ready to ﬁght another day.

name: Grizz Snapback
description:
The Grizz Snapback, available in a variety of colors.

Embroidered design on the front with the HYDZ logo on the backside.

name: Bad Medicine / Hoodie - Pink
description:
Medicine men/women (Shamans) is a term that is very much a part of the culture of the Worlds Indigenous people and especially the Native Americans.  In my Athabascan culture Medicine people played a huge part in our survival, today it is hardly seen, used, or understood.  The elders say that when the huge influx of European people and their ways came into Alaska in the late 1800s the last Medicine people around said that, “We will lose our medicine”!  Perhaps it is the fact that we no longer struggle, use, and work with the land and the animals, which ensured our survival.  It was a much tougher, but purer way of life in every way and the wise would say, “There is something in the air that takes care of us”!
Now that being said, life’s biggest struggles often times came down to wars between tribes in a fight over land barriers that provided the furs, foods, and tools for survival.  Medicine people would be able to foresee bad times coming and some would use medicine in a bad way to try hurt the enemy.
Some Medicine men abused their powers by hurting others within their own tribes too over jealousy, lust for women, etc.  It is said that when this medicine was used wrong in a bad way, that spirit never really leaves an area and would eventually come back to the family or shaman who created it.  When traveling across the lands today, we still avoid camping or hanging out in known war lands that border our neighboring tribes.

name: Feather / Sweatpants - Black&Red
description: These sweatpants are made out of 100% cotton providing the coziest feeling, they also feature the Feather design.

name: Victory / Shirt - Red
description:
I put the knife and scalp in this to display the ruthless part of life that is required to bring balance.  Some may say that this is too much, but are we any less ruthless today with our wars?

Victory is simply a design that represents the warrior spirit in all of us.  It is a spirit that begs to dance with the power to bring us through any hardships we face in life and to enjoy the good times that follow.

name: Savage Moon / Hoodie - Black
description: This design steps away from Traditional meanings a bit, although it was partially inspired by all of the wolf clans of the Native Americans.  The wolf is also a highly respected animal of the tribes in the relative fact that it works as a family, has a strong picking order, and secures borders such as all Native Americans.  I put a modern twist along with the tomahawks on this design to display a strong and aggressive Native American spirit that is ready for the challenges of today.

name: Wolf/Raven / Shirt - Black
description: This design represents two highly respected animals and how they work together.  The raven follows the wolf for food and the wolf follows the raven when searching for game. We still watch the raven while hunting because it uses certain behavior to clue us in to where the game is. In the old stories of the last ice age and dark times, the raven is the bird that tricked the bear into giving back the sun.  This is a debt that all earth’s animals and people owe to the raven and is the reason it eats for free. The raven is also believed to be a messenger used by our past ancestors that can alert us to future hardships. The wolf, like the bear, wolverine and lynx is one of the old animals and it has unique values that apply to it when harvested.  We follow strict traditional steps when skinning and disposing the wolf carcass.  We never put or skin the animal in our place of residence.  There are a certain number of joints that we cut before we put the carcass back in the land far from any trail used by humans.

name: HYDZ Decal Pack
description:
Decal Pack contains 3 different decals:

HYDZ LOGO, 11x2 inches

SAVAGE MOON, 8x5 inches
-Features the Savage Moon design, with a wolf howling at the moon along with a skull embodying the strong Native American spirit.

BEAR PAW, 8x6 inches
-This decal features the bear paw design, detailing a feather and a bear paw, and the HYDZ logo.

name: Feather / Sweatpants - Black&Blue
description: These sweatpants are made out of 100% cotton providing the coziest feeling, they also feature the Feather design.

name: Butterfly / Yoga Pants - Black
description: These drawstring yoga pants are made out of 80% cotton and 20% polyester, ensuring quality as well as comfort.

name: Warrior / Coat - Black
description:
This design was done out of respect for all of our past Native warriors who played the vital role of securing the borders for their land.  There were many wars between different Native American tribes.  I did this not to ignite any old bad feelings, but to give respect to the ones that put it down for their tribes to secure the safety of their people.  Every tribe has stories of those who protected their lands animals and resources that provided food and clothing.  Today all Native Americans have no more need for this conflict.  Out of the millions of Americans in the U.S. today, all tribes share the same unique traditional values and this has bonded all in a way that was never imagined by our ancestors.

This piece is a custom Carhartt® winter coat. The outside of the hood is hand crafted by an Alaskan Native, Selina DeWilde-Alexander, lined with the traditional wolf/wolverine ruff designed to keep you warm and keep the wind chill out. The wolf ruff is the lighter colored fur on the outside; it has longer guard hairs that are meant to block the wind from you while the wolverine ruff, the lighter colored fur closer to the inside is known to be resistant to icing up from your breath in the cold Alaskan winters. The Alaskan Natives call this style of ruff the "Sunshine Ruff".

The coat can be customized even further with different colors for the embroidery or the garment itself. It can also have a name or word embroidered with your placement of choice. 

For special order, contact Ricko DeWilde at:
phone. 1-907-687-3930
email. skinz907@yahoo.com

name: B-Spear / Shirt - Blue
description: The bear spear played a crucial role in the survival of the Native Alaskan tribes. Before the introduction of firearms in the 1800s, the bear spear was used for hunting grizzly bears.  It was also the last step in the journey to becoming a warrior.  The grizzly was and still is considered to be a large threat to the survival of many game animals in the Native Alaskan lands.  Moose, caribou, black bear, beaver, etc. are staple foods of my people, and the overpopulation of grizzlies can play a vital role in the survival of the animals.  When a grizzly was around, it was hunted to ensure the survival of the people and the animals.  When encountered, the warrior would provoke the grizzly to attack, if needed, by shooting it with a bow and arrow.  The hunter would then wait in a kneeling position and let the charging animal come to him.  In the right moment, he would then use his bear spear to impale the bear, ensuring his ability to provide for and protect his tribe.  The image of the half Indian and half bear in this design is a symbol of the warrior’s ability to obtain the strength of the bear by passing the final step in the journey to manhood.

name: Butterfly / Spaghetti Strap - White
description:
The Butterfly spaghetti strap is made of 100% cotton giving the garment the softest feel available.

The design is inspired by the silent beauty of butterflies.

name: Butterfly / Spaghetti Strap - Black
description:
The Butterfly spaghetti strap is made of 100% cotton giving the garment the softest feel available.

The design is inspired by the silent beauty of butterflies.

name: Eagles Locked / Shirt - Black
description: This design is simple in its meaning, just out of the respect for the most powerful bird of the sky. The eagle is a symbol of strength for many tribes, clans, and people of this earth.  When challenged for rights to a fish or any piece of food, eagles may lock in flight and start their spiral.  The last to let go has rights to the food and will also establish a first in rank should this conflict ever arise again.  Eagles also lock in flight during mating.  The sight of Eagles locked in flight will inspire anyone to think in awe of the nerves one must have to conquer the social challenges of life, whether it be for love or to obtain a level of picking order

name: Moose Skull / Shirt - Black
description: This design was done just simply because the moose has such a huge force in bringing our people together. Teamwork, traditional skills, and family values are passed on to the younger ones by the elders when harvesting and putting away meat from this animal. Knowledge on hunting skills, hunting areas, building and using smoke houses, and the work in the packing and gutting of this animal rewards families with food for months, strength, and stories for years to come.

name: Savage Moon / Shirt - Black
description:
SAVAGE MOON.

Black Men's shirt featuring the Savage Moon design.

This design steps away from Traditional meanings a bit, although it was partially inspired by all of the wolf clans of the Native Americans.  The wolf is also a highly respected animal of the tribes in the relative fact that it works as a family, has a strong picking order, and secures borders such as all Native Americans.  I put a modern twist along with the tomahawks on this design to display a strong and aggressive Native American spirit that is ready for the challenges of today.

Every tribe has stories of those who protected their lands animals and resources that provided food and clothing.  Today all Native Americans have no more need for this conflict.  Out of the millions of Americans in the U.S. today, all tribes share the same unique traditional values and this has bonded all in a way that was never imagined by our ancestors.

name: Buffalo Skull / Shirt - Black
description: This design is a symbol of the strength of the Native American spirit.  The buffalo skull is a signature symbol of natural power. The grizzly’s left hand is a symbol of the animal’s strongest hand.  It is common knowledge passed on in the Native Alaskan’s teachings.  One must know this when hunting the animal because if wounded and/or tracked, the grizzly tends to circle left and come back on its trail to wait in ambush.  The war shield and Bear spear is powerful images that displays some of what was needed to secure ones protection from the elements of life in the days of our ancestors.  The pipe was included in this design because it is a universal symbol of relaxation and good times no matter what Is being thrown at you in life.

name: Whaling / Hoodie - Black
description:
I can't speak too much on this main whaling piece, for I am not an Eskimo, nor do I whale.  I did this design because of the great respect that I have for all of my Eskimo friends.  From the times I hung with them on the streets to hunting wolves, bears, seals, caribou, etc. throughout the Eskimo regions.  We have always gotten along well, and they have always treated me with the same amount, if not greater respect.  I have been invited to go in the past, and one day I will most likely go whaling with my northern most Native friends.
I did the cross on the hood, intermingled with the harpoon tips to signify the embrace of Christianity and the old way of religion that is so strong in our Native culture today.  Also, I wanted to symbolize how hunting is one of the key aspects to our Native American religion.  In all tribes, to my knowledge and experience, the animal will give itself to you if you are a good and deserving person.  It is believed that there are many ways that a person can ruin this luck.  For example, a person brags too much, doesn't help others, acts out selfishly, speaks in a manner that they are out to get or kill an animal, brags about the size of an animal they harvested, does not care for the meat properly, etc..  In this aspect of Native religion, one must have a positive influence and effect on, and towards people, and Mother Nature.  This type of religion, one does not imply or speak about how religious they are, they simply walk the walk, and in the end the mother earth and the creator will gift one with great luck when bringing home food and hides to their family and community.

name: Moose Skull / Hoodie - Black
description: This design was done just simply because the moose has such a huge force in bringing our people together.  Teamwork, traditional skills, and family values are passed on to the younger ones by the elders when harvesting and putting away meat from this animal.
